qas.question: What was President Clinton's response to the claim that affirmative action was not hurting the white middle class.?

context: There are a multitude of supporters as well as opponents to the policy of affirmative action. Many presidents throughout the last century have failed to take a very firm stance on the policy, and the public has had to discern the president's opinion for themselves. <a0_0><b5_0>Bill Clinton<b5_0/><a0_0/>, however, made his stance on affirmative action very clear in a speech on July 19, 1995, nearly <a1_0><b6_0>two and a half years<b6_0/><a1_0/> after his inauguration. In his speech, he discussed the history in the United States that brought the policy into fruition: slavery, Jim Crow, and segregation. Clinton also mentioned a point similar to <a2_0>President <b7_0>Lyndon B. Johnson's "Freedom is not Enough"<b7_0/><a2_0/> speech, and declared that <a3_0>just <b8_0>outlawing discrimination<b8_0/><a3_0/> in the country would not be enough to give everyone in America equality. He addressed the arguments that affirmative action hurt the white middle class and said that <a4_0>the <b9_0>policy was not the source of their problems<b9_0/><a4_0/>.
